posts.post_content:
For those saying he does easily to bolt, read up on your rules. You can't a planeswalker as soon as it comes into play. The active player has to pass priority to the other player before they can play instants, and since +2 loyalty counters is part of the cost of Venser's first ability, Venser will have 5 loyalty before any bolts may be cast by an opponent.  
  
And to those saying he's in the wrong colors, guess again. Try building U/W control with this guy, Sun Titan, Frost Titan, and Wall of Omens, and then tell me he's in the wrong colors. The unblockable ability is just icing on the cake, and can win when your opponent has an army of blockers, is at 12 and you have 2 titans. It's been done.  
  
The point of this guy is to blink your permanents. Blink Sun Titan, play Day of Judgment, EoT get back Sun Titan and Wall of Omens and draw a card. It's pretty good.  
  
And yes, the text says "target permanent you own." So after your opponent plays Volition Reins on your Jace, you can Venser ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

And to those saying he's in the wrong colors, guess again. Try building U/W control with this guy, Sun Titan, Frost Titan, and Wall of Omens, and then tell me he's in the wrong colors. The unblockable ability is just icing on the cake, and can win when your opponent has an army of blockers, is at 12 and you have 2 titans. It's been done.

The point of this guy is to blink your permanents. Blink Sun Titan, play Day of Judgment, EoT get back Sun Titan and Wall of Omens and draw a card. It's pretty good.

posts.post_content:
Venser is probably the only one who can use his first ability to 'cleanse' -1/-1 counters of your creatures, a great deal consider that you don't see many cards that can do this.
  
   
And here's a possible combo for Elspeth Tirel and Venser working together, with Elspeth creating tokens the first time in the turn, then let Venser exile her, returning her with 4 loyalty couners again. You can keep doing this each turn till you're satisfied withthe number of soldier tokens at your command, and they also act as your shield against constant harassment, three soldiers each turn to block your opponent's desperate assault.
  
   
When you felt you had enough, proliferate or wait a turn for Elspeth to charge up, have Venser phase himself out of the game before letting Elspeth clean the board, while he comes back with his 3 counters. Sound strategy, bet most players didn't think of that but it works.
  
   
Oh, and um, Bathory, care to explain your issues with 'arms'? '''>\_>'''
  
(lol)
posts.html:
Venser is probably the only one who can use his first ability to 'cleanse' -1/-1 counters of your creatures, a great deal consider that you don't see many cards that can do this.

And here's a possible combo for Elspeth Tirel and Venser working together, with Elspeth creating tokens the first time in the turn, then let Venser exile her, returning her with 4 loyalty couners again. You can keep doing this each turn till you're satisfied withthe number of soldier tokens at your command, and they also act as your shield against constant harassment, three soldiers each turn to block your opponent's desperate assault.

When you felt you had enough, proliferate or wait a turn for Elspeth to charge up, have Venser phase himself out of the game before letting Elspeth clean the board, while he comes back with his 3 counters. Sound strategy, bet most players didn't think of that but it works.

Oh, and um, Bathory, care to explain your issues with 'arms'? '''>_>'''
(lol)

posts.post_content:
"oh yeah, guys, why is it that on the MTG site, they say venser is a "new breed" of planeswalker? don't all planeswalkers teleport when they planeswalk to a new plane?"  
~by GeronimoMartinez  
  
This is a reverence to the mending of the multiverse, which came after the phyrexian assault of dominara I believe. Yes his powers are similar to the current planeswalkers when it comes to planeswalking, but he is flavor wise the first of this breed of planeswalker.

posts.post_content: Venser is excellent with [Glimmerpoint Stag](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glimmerpoint Stag). When the stag comes back into play at the end of your turn after being bounced with Venser, you can exile an opponent's permanent (such as, say, their planeswalker) for the entirety of their next turn, as it will not be returning to play until the end of *their* turn.
posts.html:
Venser is excellent with Glimmerpoint Stag. When the stag comes back into play at the end of your turn after being bounced with Venser, you can exile an opponent's permanent (such as, say, their planeswalker) for the entirety of their next turn, as it will not be returning to play until the end of their turn.

posts.post_content:
Way cooler than Jace because Venser actually requires you to play smart: how powerful he is is determined by how you built your deck and how you play it. You could play lots of defensive creatures with ETB effects and focus on his +2: card advantage (plus threat of ultimate), or you could mix in some aggro elements so his -1 is also relevant.
  
   
Seriously, we need more cards like this, and less cards that are so powerful that they can do essentially anything anytime alone.
posts.html:
Way cooler than Jace because Venser actually requires you to play smart: how powerful he is is determined by how you built your deck and how you play it. You could play lots of defensive creatures with ETB effects and focus on his +2: card advantage (plus threat of ultimate), or you could mix in some aggro elements so his -1 is also relevant.

Seriously, we need more cards like this, and less cards that are so powerful that they can do essentially anything anytime alone.

posts.post_content:
@ channelblaze:  
  
113.2. An effect that creates an emblem is written “ gets an emblem with .” This means  
that puts an emblem with into the command zone. The emblem is both owned and  
controlled by that player.  
  
113.3. An emblem has no characteristics other than the abilities defined by the effect that created it. In  
particular, an emblem has no name, no types, no mana cost, no color, and no expansion symbol.  
  
Essentially, because emblems are colorless, your assumption is correct. You could use Venser's emblem to exile permanents that have protection from white or from blue. Think of it as YOU getting the ability. YOU are a colorless noncard nontoken nonspell source.
posts.html:
@ channelblaze:

113.2. An effect that creates an emblem is written “ gets an emblem with .” This means
that puts an emblem with into the command zone. The emblem is both owned and
controlled by that player.

113.3. An emblem has no characteristics other than the abilities defined by the effect that created it. In
particular, an emblem has no name, no types, no mana cost, no color, and no expansion symbol.

Essentially, because emblems are colorless, your assumption is correct. You could use Venser's emblem to exile permanents that have protection from white or from blue. Think of it as YOU getting the ability. YOU are a colorless noncard nontoken nonspell source.
